item.title: Disable torrents on router
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:4, topic:333250”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=429663.msg3154803#msg3154803 date=1268935891]

Why don’t you want to only allow you and your family to connect through your router? You could potentially get into big trouble letting others use your connection.

You could only allow connections to certain ports, like 80 (http) and 443 (https)
[/quote]They are my family, but they think I’m being selfish when I tell them not to download all day. It’s not that I care about piracy, but BT throttle my connection when people torrent on it and it takes weeks of innocent surfing for it to get back up to normal speed.

I can allow/block ports but I don’t think there is a standard port for torrents? Having a strict whitelist policy will cause trouble because they wont be able to play online games or use msn etc.

What happens if you disable UPnP? It might screw with some other apps but it really shouldn’t. You could always set up Qos to give you most of the bandwidth (by throttling your family)[/quote]
What exactly does UPnP allow people on the network do? Remember I still have to use the network, so don’t want to stop myself from running any half-interesting programs.

I could setup QoS but I don’t think that’d be too useful, because it’d just allow them to use all the available bandwidth which would be about 90% and it’s not really the performance hit I’m worried about, it’s the fact that BT automatically throttle the entire internet connection when people torrent frequently. If I could use QoS to reduce their speed to like 10kbps or a small percentage of available bandwidth, that’d be good because BT’s automated system wouldn’t class that as heavy file sharing.
